natural problem: What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged?
natural solution: To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes is_prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
and swap_digits :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> is_prime n = is_prime (swap_digits n)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 13 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 98 \<longrightarrow> is_prime n"
shows  "sum is_prime {13..98} = 418"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418
 ### Proof
 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes is_prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
and swap_digits :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> is_prime n = is_prime (swap_digits n)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 13 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 98 \<longrightarrow> is_prime n"
shows  "sum is_prime {13..98} = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For all two-digit prime numbers, if swapping the digits still results in a prime number, what is the sum of all prime numbers from 13 to 98? The final answer is 418.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and sum :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. p n = (prime n \<and> 12 < n \<and> n < 99 \<and> prime (swap_digits n))"
and h1 : "sum = (\<Sum>n | p n. n)"
shows  "sum = 418"
a_1.formal solution:

 *)

a_1.informal problem: Find the sum of all prime numbers between 12 and 99 inclusive, where the number formed by swapping the digits of the number is also prime. The final answer is 418.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime_sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime_sum n = (if n < 13 \<or> n > 98 then 0 else (if prime n then n else 0))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime_sum (n div 10 + (n mod 10) * 10) = prime_sum n"
shows  "(\<Sum> i = 13..98. prime_sum i) = 418"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418
 ### Proof
 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime_sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime_sum n = (if n < 13 \<or> n > 98 then 0 else (if prime n then n else 0))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime_sum (n div 10 + (n mod 10) * 10) = prime_sum n"
shows  "(\<Sum> i = 13..98. prime_sum i) = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a function prime_sum defined as follows: for any natural number n, if n is less than 13 or greater than 98, prime_sum(n) equals 0. If n is a prime number within the range 13 to 98, then prime_sum(n) equals n. Otherwise, prime_sum(n) equals 0. This function also has the property that swapping the tens and units digit of n doesn't change its value, i.e., prime_sum of (n div 10 + (n mod 10) * 10) equals prime_sum of n. What is the sum of prime_sum(i) from i equals 13 to 98? The final answer is 418.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and sum :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime (p n) \<longrightarrow> (p n > 12 \<and> p n < 99) \<and> prime (p (n div 10 + (n mod 10) * 10))"
and h1 : "sum = (\<Sum>n. p n)"
shows  "sum = 418"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418
 ### Proof
 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and sum :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime (p n) \<longrightarrow> (p n > 12 \<and> p n < 99) \<and> prime (p (n div 10 + (n mod 10) * 10))"
and h1 : "sum = (\<Sum>n. p n)"
shows  "sum = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Let $p(n)$ be a prime number function such that for every natural number $n$, if $p(n)$ is prime, then $p(n)$ is greater than $12$ and less than $99$, and also $p$ of the number obtained by reversing the digits of $n$ is prime. Find the sum of all $p(n)$. The final answer is $418$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool" and flip :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "p n = is_prime n"
and h1 : "flip n = n mod 10 * 10 + n div 10"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> p n \<and> p (flip n) \<longrightarrow> n > 12 \<and> n < 99"
shows  "sum p {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> p n \<and> p (flip n)} = 418"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418
 ### Proof
 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool" and flip :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "p n = is_prime n"
and h1 : "flip n = n mod 10 * 10 + n div 10"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> p n \<and> p (flip n) \<longrightarrow> n > 12 \<and> n < 99"
shows  "sum p {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> p n \<and> p (flip n)} = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Let $p(n)$ be the predicate that checks if $n$ is a prime number and let $flip(n)$ be a function that reverses the digits of a two-digit number $n$. Find the sum of all two-digit prime numbers $n$ such that both $n$ and $flip(n)$ are prime numbers. The final answer is 418.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum_primes :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 13 \<and> n \<le> 98 \<longrightarrow> (prime n \<and> prime (swap_digits n)) \<longrightarrow> sum_primes n = n"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> n. sum_primes n) {n. n \<in> {13..98} \<and> prime n \<and> prime (swap_digits n)} = 418"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418
 ### Proof
 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sum_primes :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 13 \<and> n \<le> 98 \<longrightarrow> (prime n \<and> prime (swap_digits n)) \<longrightarrow> sum_primes n = n"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> n. sum_primes n) {n. n \<in> {13..98} \<and> prime n \<and> prime (swap_digits n)} = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the sum of all prime numbers between 13 and 98, inclusive, such that the number obtained by swapping its digits is also prime. The final answer is 418.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: int and is_prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and digit_swap :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. is_prime p = (1 < p \<and> (\<forall> m. m dvd p \<longrightarrow> m = 1 \<or> m = p))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. digit_swap n = (n mod 10) * 10 + n div 10"
and h2 : "sum = (\<Sum> p = 13..98. if is_prime p \<and> is_prime (digit_swap p) then p else 0)"
shows  "sum = 418"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418
 ### Proof
 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sum :: int and is_prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and digit_swap :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> p. is_prime p = (1 < p \<and> (\<forall> m. m dvd p \<longrightarrow> m = 1 \<or> m = p))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. digit_swap n = (n mod 10) * 10 + n div 10"
and h2 : "sum = (\<Sum> p = 13..98. if is_prime p \<and> is_prime (digit_swap p) then p else 0)"
shows  "sum = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the sum of all two-digit prime numbers between 13 and 98 inclusive, that remain prime when their two digits are reversed. The final answer is 418.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime_sum :: int
assumes h0 : "prime_sum = sum_list [x. prime x \<and> x > 12 \<and> x < 99 \<and> prime (swap_digits x)]"
shows  "prime_sum = 418"

(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418

 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime_sum :: int
assumes h0 : "prime_sum = sum_list [x. prime x \<and> x > 12 \<and> x < 99 \<and> prime (swap_digits x)]"
shows  "prime_sum = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the sum of all prime numbers greater than 12 and less than 99, which remain prime even if their digits are reversed. The total sum is 418.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "prime = (\<lambda>n. 1 < n \<and> (\<forall>m\<in>{2..<n}. n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "is_prime = (\<lambda>n. prime n \<and> prime (n mod 10 * 10 + n div 10))"
shows  "(\<Sum>n | 12 < n \<and> n < 99 \<and> is_prime n. n) = 418"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418
 ### Proof
 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "prime = (\<lambda>n. 1 < n \<and> (\<forall>m\<in>{2..<n}. n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "is_prime = (\<lambda>n. prime n \<and> prime (n mod 10 * 10 + n div 10))"
shows  "(\<Sum>n | 12 < n \<and> n < 99 \<and> is_prime n. n) = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the sum of all two-digit prime numbers whose rearrangement (swapping the tens and units digit) is also prime. The final sum is 418.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and interchange :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n = (1 < n \<and> (\<forall>m. m \<ge> 2 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. interchange n = (n mod 10) * 10 + n div 10"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 13 \<and> n \<le> 98 \<and> prime n \<and> prime (interchange n) \<longrightarrow> prime n"
shows  "(\<Sum> n = 13..98. if prime n \<and> prime (interchange n) then n else 0) = 418"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all of the two-digit primes that are greater than 12 but less than 99 and are still prime when their two digits are interchanged? The final Answer is 418
 ### Proof
 To solve this question we need to think about what the units digit of a prime number could be. A two-digit prime could end in 1, 3, 7 or 9; thus, we need to examine primes only in the 10s, 30s, 70s and 90s because when the digits are switched the tens digit will become the units digit.
 The primes greater than 12 but less than 99 that are still prime when their two digits are interchanged are 13, 17, 31, 37, 71, 73, 79 and 97. Their sum is $\boxed{418}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and interchange :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n = (1 < n \<and> (\<forall>m. m \<ge> 2 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. interchange n = (n mod 10) * 10 + n div 10"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 13 \<and> n \<le> 98 \<and> prime n \<and> prime (interchange n) \<longrightarrow> prime n"
shows  "(\<Sum> n = 13..98. if prime n \<and> prime (interchange n) then n else 0) = 418"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
A prime number is defined as an integer greater than 1 that has no positive integer divisors other than 1 and itself. Given a number, the "interchange" operation is defined as moving the last digit of the number to the front. For example, the interchange of 23 is 32. 

The task is to find the sum of all prime numbers between 13 and 98 (inclusive), for which their "interchange" is also a prime number. The final answer is 418.
